C.

Hyper-V Replication is the core feature for replicating virtual machines. You need to enable it on each VM you want to protect. This action initiates the replication process and allows you to configure settings like the replica server, recovery points, and replication frequency.

E. 

In a workgroup environment, Kerberos authentication is not typically used. Certificate-based authentication is the recommended and more secure method for Hyper-V Replica in workgroups. You will need to configure both Host1 and Host2 to use certificate-based authentication. Additionally, you will need to ensure that TCP port 443 (or the port you configure for HTTPS) is open in the firewalls of both servers to allow replication traffic.

F. 

Host2 will be the server receiving the replicated virtual machines. You must enable the Hyper-V Replica role on Host2 to designate it as the Replica server. This action configures Host2 to accept replication connections and store the replica VMs.

Where is Failover initiated?
1. Test - On the replica virtual machine

Planned failover performs prerequisites checks to ensure zero data loss. It checks that the primary virtual machine is shut down before 
beginning the failover. After the virtual machine is failed over, it starts replicating the changes back to the primary site when it's available.

Failover. Pick the latest or other recovery point if configured. A new test virtual machine will be created and started on the secondary site.

Unplanned Failover from Hyper-V Manager or Failover Clustering Manager. You can recover from the latest recovery point or from
